items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are forecast to rise on the River Blackwater and The Cove Brook as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible tomorrow morning 11/03/23, especially in the Swallowfield area area. Levels started to rise earlier in the week due to the heavy rainfall after a drier period and are expected to continue to respond to the showers.

Further showers are forecast over today. We expect river levels to begin to fall over the weekend..

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening, 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Warwick river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall and snow melt overnight.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected currently, 10/03/23.  .    Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon between Rugby and Bidford including Warwick, Stratford upon Avon, caravan parks and farmland. 
Further rainfall and snow is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday 10/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. 
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued.
This message will be updated by 16:00 on 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall and forecasted to remain high today.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible from 10am today 10 March 2023.  We expect flooding to affect areas between Kinnersley Manor and Sidlow, although there may be other areas of minor flooding.   
Rain is expected to clear from late morning today.  We expect river levels to rise along the catchment throughout today before receding.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
This message will be updated by 5pm 10 March 2023, or sooner if the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise at the Dernford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last 24 hours. Consequently, the risk of flooding is expected to continue. Flooding is affecting River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated  this afternoon, 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Flooding continues.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.  We expect river levels to rise until 14:00 today 10/03/23. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated by 10:00 on 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 4 am today 10 March 2023 and will continue overnight into 11 March 2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads is expected around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst particularly on and around Balls Green and Ashurst.  

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until 6 am on 11 March 2023 .

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses between and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded

This message will be updated  this evening, 10 March 2023, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels have risen on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of footpaths and farmland is possible over today 10/03/23, especially in the Godalming and Bordon areas. Levels started to rise earlier in the week due to the heavy rainfall after a drier period and are expected to continue to respond to the showers particularly on the Hell Ditch. 

Further showers are forecast over today. We expect river levels to begin to fall over the weekend.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening, 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Evenlode as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and footpaths is possible today, 10/03/23, especially in the Evenlode area. 
The forecast today is for spells of snow and rain this morning, with some isolated rainfall showers possible this afternoon. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Evesham river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this afternoon.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. Predicted peaks:- Evesham 1.9m to 2.2m this evening, Friday, 10/03/23, Bredon 1.7m to 2.0m overnight.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 19:00 on 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall and snow melt overnight.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning, Friday 10/03/23.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.   
Further rain and snowfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday 10/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued
This message will be updated by 16:00 on 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is high and rising. In the last 2 days, more than half a month's rain (30mm) has been recorded at Barcombe. From 07:00 10/03/2023 Barcombe Mills road is likely to be affected by flood water, and could become impassable. It is possible minor flooding could also affect the Anchor Inn and gardens of properties at Barcombe Mills. Minor flood impacts could also affect rural roads, including Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next 2 days but further persistent rain is currently predicted on Sunday. The river should begin to fall by 17:00 Friday evening (10/03/2023) but will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the next week. Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Some roads may become impassable, including Barcombe Mills road, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 18:00 10/03/2023.

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

This message will be updated  this afternoon, 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.
Further rain and snow is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high Throughout Friday, 10/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.

items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Nene area. This means that the River Nene is now rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from the early morning of Friday 10th March 2023 onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. Further rainfall is expected this morning. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 10/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole..
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding is possible at the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. from 11:00 AM on 10/03/2023.
Further light rainfall is forecast this this afternoon and evening.
River levels are high but steady, but the risk of flooding to roads remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Following prolonged rainfall since Wednesday, river levels have risen in the Medway catchment. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Medway particularly footpaths and riverside areas around East Farleigh, Tovil, Lockmeadow in  Maidstone and further downstream towards Aylesford.

  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday 10 March and overnight into Saturday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 

Please avoid riverside paths and subways in Maidstone Town Centre.  
This message will be updated  this evening, Friday 10 March 2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Bishops Hull river gauge as a result persistent heavy rainfall and snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between noon on 09/03/2023 and 18:00 tomorrow, 10/03/2023.  We expect flooding to affect roads around Hillfarrance, Bradford on Tone, Lane End Road at Ham and the Creech St Michael to Henlade road. Bradford on Tone ringbanks will be bankfull.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until 10:00 on 10/03/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking and clearing weed screens.

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Friday 10th March.  

Following heavy rainfall overnight, river levels remain high, and are due to peak by this afternoon.  The risk of flooding will remain into Friday Evening, with further heavy showers throughout the day. 

This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers. We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and will update this message by 5pm on Friday or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Bradford on Avon gauge at Bradford on Avon  as a result of heavy rainfall and snow melt, with approximately 20mm of rain fallen in the last 48 hours. River levels on the River Avon at Great Somerford, River Avon at Bradford on Avon, River Avon at Bathford and Semington Brook at Semington are rising through this evening (the 09 March 2023). Currently we are not forecasting flood warning thresholds to be met. 

This message will be updated on Friday the 10th March 2023, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to effect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. We are closely monitoring the situation.

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 10/03/2023. Flooding is affecting Roads close to the bridges at Harrold, Oakley, Felmersham and Radwell.  

The roads at Harrold, Oakley, Radwell and Felmersham may become impassable due to flood water. This message applies to only the roads. 
The Environment Agency are liaising with Bedford Borough Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads.  
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Friday 10 March. River levels are gradually rising, and will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas along the River Mardyke between North Stifford and Purfleet. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for rain through today, followed by a dry day tomorrow, but then further rain pushing in Saturday evening into Sunday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Saturday 11 December.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1pm and 3pm today, Friday 10th March. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level at Southend of 3.64 mAODN at 2pm today, Friday 10th March, which is 0.85m above tide tables, wind Force 5, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm today, Friday 10th March.

items.message:
Forecast stormy weather conditions and high tide levels are expected to impact the seafront as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest at 19:30 today, 09/03/23. Flooding to the promenade/seafront is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Any flooding could affect the Hunstanton seafront.
   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.  
The local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 3.86 mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.33m. Including a forecast adjustment of 0.10m. The final forecast tide level is 4.29 mAOD. The forecast wind direction is easterly. The forecast wind strength is Force 7.

This message will be updated  this evening, 09/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:45pm and 2:45pm today, Friday 10th March. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may experience some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.90 mAODN at 1:45pm today, Friday 10th March, which is 0.67m above tide tables, wind Force 6, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm today, Friday 10th March.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued for the coast of the Isle of Sheppey and the coast from Kemsley to Seasalter as a result of the high tide expected this afternoon. The tide will be at its highest between 1:30pm and 3:15pm today, 10/03/2023. High tide is expected at 2:15pm. The forecast water level at Sheerness is 3.60m AOD. Areas of concern include Faversham and Conyer and low lying land nearest the sea such as promenades and coastal footpaths.
Once the high tide tomorrow afternoon has passed, conditions are expected to improve from 4pm onwards. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are operating our defences and structures at Queenborough Barrier, Aylesford Gates, Front Brents and Canal Basin.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads between, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 5pm, 10/03/2023.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:

High tide is expected at 2:15pm. The forecast water level at Sheerness is 3.60m AOD. Areas of concern include Royal Pier Road, Gravesend, and low lying land nearest the sea such as promenades and coastal footpaths.
Once the high tide tomorrow afternoon has passed, conditions are expected to improve from 4pm onwards. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are operating our defences and structures at Queenborough Barrier, Aylesford Gates, Front Brents and Canal Basin.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads between, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued for the Medway estuary as a result of the high tide expected this afternoon. The tide will be at its highest between 1:30pm and 3:15pm today, 10/03/2023. High tide is expected at 2:15pm. The forecast water level at Sheerness is 3.60m AOD. Areas of concern include Upnor and Canal Road, Strood, and low lying land nearest the sea such as promenades and coastal footpaths.
Once the high tide tomorrow afternoon has passed, conditions are expected to improve from 4pm onwards. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are operating our defences and structures at Queenborough Barrier, Aylesford Gates, Front Brents and Canal Basin.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads between, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 5pm, 10/03/2023.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:45pm and 2:45pm, Friday 10 March. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.90mAODN at 1:45pm, Friday 10 March, which is 0.67m above tide tables, wind Force 6, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 3pm today, Friday 10 March.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:30pm and 2:30pm, Friday 10 March. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.56mAODN at 1:30pm, Friday 10th March, which is 0.69m above tide tables, wind Force 6, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 3pm today, Friday 10th March.

items.description: The Essex coast from Fobbing to Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 1pm and 3pm, Friday 10 March. Areas most at risk are within low lying land around,  Corringham, Tilbury, Grays, Thurrock and Purfleet. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.64mAODN at 2pm, Friday 10 March, which is 0.85m above tide tables, wind Force 5, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm today, Friday 10 March.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:45pm and 2:45pm today, Friday 10th March. Tide levels will be high at Battlesbridge, and Hullbridge riversides. Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.90 mAODN at 1:45pm today, Friday 10th March, which is 0.67m above tide tables, wind Force 6, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 3pm today, Friday 10th March.

The unsettled weather which elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area. This morning’s tide at Portsmouth (00:51 on 10/02/2023) came in 0.15m above forecast. Tide levels are now reducing. However, on early Monday (13/03/2023), the tide level is slightly elevated, but currently flooding impacts are not expected. We will issue further advice if the tide forecast increases and the risk of flooding returns.

The unsettled weather which elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area. This morning’s tide at Beaulieu (00:18 on 10/02/2023) came in 0.13m above forecast. Tide levels are now reducing. However, on early Monday morning (13/03/2023), the tide level is slightly elevated, but currently flooding impacts are not expected. We will issue further advice if the tide forecast increases and the risk of flooding returns.

Strong winds and large waves are predicted for Friday morning and Monday 13/03/2023. However, tides will now gradually fall to neaps. Friday’s afternoon tide is predicted to be 50 cm lower than Friday’s early morning tide. Tides over the weekend and next week are forecast to be even lower. Other than a small amount of spray on Friday and Monday, there should be less flood risk in the week ahead. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

Strong winds and large waves are predicted for Friday morning and Monday 13/03/2023. However, tides will now gradually fall to neaps. Friday’s afternoon tide is predicted to be 50 cm lower than Friday’s early morning tide. Tides over the weekend and next week are forecast to be even lower. Other than a small amount of spray on Friday and Monday, there should be less flood risk in the week ahead. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: South Devon coast from Dawlish Warren to Seaton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council
Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
A tidal surge and Spring tides could increase the water levels around high water and overtopping of sea defences is possible.  Forecast high water is 08:00 on 10/03/2023 with a Force 6 North Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Weymouth, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  The flood alert is triggered at Preston Beach. Flooding is possible at Castletown, Preston Beach, Poole Harbour, Bournemouth Beach, Hengistbury Head and Christchurch Harbour   

We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.  
This message will be updated Friday, 10/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

A tidal surge coinciding with spring tides will increase the water levels around high water and overtopping of sea defences is possible. The flood alert criteria are triggered from the Chiswell Beach.  Forecast high water is 07:45 on 10/03/2023 with a Force 6 Northwesterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Portland Tidal gauge, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Charmouth, Seatown, Bothenhampton, Burton Freshwater, Burton Bradstock, Cogdean Beach, Chesil Beach, West Fleet, East Fleet and Chiswell   

We are closely monitoring the situation
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.  
This message will be updated tomorrow, 10/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Warwick Old Budbrooke Road river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall and snow melt.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible to begin between 01:00 and 02:00 Friday morning, 10/03/23.  Flooding is affecting Properties along Lodge Crescent.
Further rainfall and snow is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday 10/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please activate any property flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers and avoid contact with flood water.  Call 999 if in immediate danger.
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Hamerton river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting Alconbury Brook at Hamerton, The Alconburys, Little Stukeley and Brampton.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high and rising. Since Wednesday, 35mm of rain has been recorded at Cowfold, which is more than half a month's rain. From 05:30 10/03/2023 flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may begin to approach buildings too. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next 2 days, but further persistent rain is currently predicted on Sunday. The river should begin to fall by 14:00 10/03/2023. Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall, however the river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the next week. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:00 10/03/2023.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Harpers Brook and Willow Brook area. This means that Harpers Brook and Willow Brook is now rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from early morning of Friday 10th March 2023 onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout today and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. Further rainfall is expected this morning. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 10/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River East Glen, River West Glen, River Tham

items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the East and West Glens area. This means that the East and West Glens are rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from the early morning of Friday 10th March 2023 onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. Further rainfall is expected throughout today. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 10/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Little Alne river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rain and snow melt overnight.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning, 10/03/23.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks.
Further rain and snowfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday 10/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued. 
This message will be updated by 16:00 on 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the South Kesteven area. This means that the River Witham in South Kesteven is now rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from the early morning of Friday 10th March 2023 onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. Further rainfall/snow is expected this morning. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 10/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued
This message will be updated by 16:00 on 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Perdiswell river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is imminent.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Barbourne Brook from the M5 to Barbourne including Perdiswell and Blackpole Industrial Estate.   
Further rain and snow is forecast this morning. 
We expect river levels to remain high today Friday 10/03/23. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated  by 14:00 on 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Dartford Creek and The Mardyke to the Thames Barrier
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Barking and Dagenham, Bexley, Greater London, Greenwich, Havering, Kent, Newham, Thurrock

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and a closure of the Thames Barrier.

Water will be maintained within the downstream network of flood defences, which include river walls, embankments and flood gates, however flooding of low lying footpaths and open spaces is possible for 1-2 hours around high tide.

The forecast high tide at the Thames Barrier is at 15:00 on 10/03/2023.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground ensuring all flood gates are closed.

Members of the public are advised to avoid floodwater and also to keep abreast of updates to the forecast.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 10/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Friday 10 March. River levels are gradually rising, and will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and,  Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for rain through today, followed by a dry day tomorrow, but then further rain pushing in Saturday evening into Sunday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Saturday 11 March.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Friday 10 March. River levels are gradually rising, and will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Haverhill, Clare and Sudbury, including Kedington, Sturmer, Steeple Bumpstead, Cavendish, Bridge Street and Long Melford. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for rain through today, followed by a dry day tomorrow, but then further rain pushing in Saturday evening into Sunday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and  will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Saturday 11 March.
